msContents.textLang: Latin with an added text in Middle English

msItem.incipit: Dominica prima aduentus domini ad primas vesperas pulsatis campanis more solito accensisque luminaribus in ecclesia
msItem.explicit: fuerat glorificabant deum et dicebant quia hic est saluator mundi Psalmus M
msItem.title: Breviary, Sarum Use
msItem.note: The temporale, ending in the 25th Sunday after Pentecost; ed. BrevSar, vols. 1–2.

msItem.incipit: In dedicacione ecclesie ad primas vesperas super psalmos hec sola antiphona O quam metuendus est locus
msItem.explicit: Hugonis episcopi Edmundi regis Cecilie uirginis et sancte Katerine uirginis
msItem.note: The dedication of a church, a list of subsidiary blessings, and notes on specific services for various feasts. Fols. 263rb–64v blank but fully bounded and ruled. In the gutter of the final (blank) leaf a co2 mark, i.e. ‘corrigitur’.

msItem.incipit: primus mensis Ianarius dicitur a lano cui fuit consecratus et dicitur ianuarius eo quod
msItem.explicit: abundunciam et pacem inter gentes et omnia prospera designat adesse

msItem.note: The calendar. Includes among red-letter feasts, ‘Cathedra sancti Petri’ (22 February), Richard of Chichester (3 April); and the translation of Edmund Rich (9 June). Among other English saints (not Cuthbert), are the translation of Swithin and an added entry for Frideswide (19 October). Fols. 273–4v are blank but ruled.

msItem.incipit: Beatus uir qui non abiit in consilio impiorum et in uia peccatorum
msItem.explicit: Omnes sancti orate pro nobis Propius esto per se uobis domine et cetera ut supra
msItem.note: The Psalter with interspersed prayers, and the canticles to ‘Nunc dimittis’, followed by a litany. There are only three lines on fol. 337v and fol. 338rv is blank but ruled.

msItem.incipit: In uigilia sancti andree apostoli ad vesperas super psalmos hec sola antiphona Unus ex duobus qui secuti sunt dominum erat andreas
msItem.explicit: fac nos eius mentis in sanctorum tuorum societatem transferri Per dominum’.
msItem.note: The Sanctorale, Andrew–Katherine, ed. BrevSar, vol. 3. Following Katherine, at fol. 522rb, the service for Saturinus and Sisininus, followed by ‘de deposicione sancti Erkenwaldi’ and ‘translacione eiusdem’ (which may be added).

msItem.rubric: In natale unius apostoli siue euangeliste
msItem.incipit: Lux perpetua lucebit sanctis tuis et eternitas temporum alleluia
msItem.explicit: sponso et sponse Cum Gloria patri Prudentes Versus Adducentur regi uirg’
msItem.note: The common of saints, ending in the service for more than one virgin. Fols. 551v–3v were originally blank but ruled.

msItem.incipit: Ad vesperas antiphona dei omnes qui estis consortes supernorum
msItem.explicit: iusti in domino secretum et post communione sicut in die omnium sanctorum
msItem.note: Added s. xv ex., in gothic textura quadrata.

msItem.incipit: Whan a man shal do homage to his chief lorde of whom he holdeth his chief maner
msItem.explicit: I owe to oure souuerain lord the king so god me helpe and his saintes

msItem.incipit: Beata appolonia virgo fuit inclita cuius in honorem
msItem.note: a suffrage for St Apollonia, largely as a charm against toothache (anglicana formata, s. xv2).
prayers and notes on the Virgin and her descent from David, texts of ‘Alma redemptoris mater’ and of ‘Speciosa facta es et suauis in deliciis’ (bastard secretary, s. xv2).

collation.formula: 18+1 (+1) 2–238 248 (–2) 25–338 [fol. 264, a booklet boundary] │ 3410 [fol. 274, a booklet boundary] │ 35–428 [fol. 338, a booklet boundary] │ 43–658 [to fol. 522, probably a booklet boundary at the end of the annual sequence] │ 66–688 698 (–8, a blank).
collation.signatures: All leaves in the first half of each quire signed (many cut away) with a quire letter, usually in red, and an arabic number for the leaf. In this system, quires 5–19 = d–s; quires 22–33 = a–M; quires 36–42 = b–h; quires 43, 45–51 = +, b–h; quire 52 has three dots and 53 a line; quires 54–62 = h–q.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
130 35–7 , with 9 mm between columns, in 36 lines to the column. No prickings; bounded and ruled in violet ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic textura semiquadrata. Punctuation by point, double point, and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: At major divisions, champes in blue on gold leaf with magenta, on bar borders with corner geometric knot and flower designs, in blue, magenta and gold leaf, full borders at the nocturns of the Psalter.
At minor divisions, alternate lombards in navy on red flourishing and gold leaf on purple or navy flourishing.
Smaller 1-line examples usually include red on purple in alternation with blue on red, as do the paraphs.

Fol. 1 has a full-page illumination: within a Lancastrian S collar, with the S’s in gold leaf, and attached to an inscription, ‘Salue Saluatore Spes Sol Sapiencia Splendor...’ with floral sprays, on a blue ground a shield noir, the five wounds gules and the four clous argent with the name ‘ihu’ or. The device is identified on banderoles as ‘Nomen saluatoris’ and the wounds described there as five different springs, e.g. ‘fons vite sempiterne’ for the wound in the side. Below, a distich ‘O qui cuncta regis mile fortissime uere│Collarium regis es dignum dignus habere’. Scott cites our MS as an example of the common use of the holy monogram in artistic contexts (1:76 n. 16); she associates the floral sprays in the frontispiece, which she identifies as ‘added’, with ‘border artist B’ of the Lydgate MS BL, MS Royal 18 D.ii, probably London work of 1516 x 1523. His hand appears again in our MS 187.

binding.p: Sewn on seven thongs. At the front, a marbled paper leaf, a modern paper flyleaf, and three medieval vellum flyleaves; at the rear, three medieval vellum flyleaves, a modern paper flyleaf, and another marbled paper leaf (vi–x).

history.provenance: The decoration on fol. 1 implies a royal provenance, certainly before 1461.
The calendar suggests Westminster Abbey / London, like the provision of a feast of Erkenwald at the end of item 6.
‘Found by me hughe fortescu In the howse of Iohn Robartes of Combmartyne’ (fol. 1v, s. xvi2: the first word written by the same hand on fol. v).
The old shelfmark ‘Abac: ij. N. 65.’ (fol. iii).
history.acquisition: ‘Liber Collegii Divi Ioannis Baptistae Oxon’ ex dono Stephani Pott Bibliopolae Londinensis Anno Domini 1610’ (fol. 1).
